Literature Review: Pericytes, the enigmatic cells that wrap around capillaries, have emerged as crucial players in the regulation of local blood flow in various organs, particularly in the brain and heart. Recent advancements in optogenetic tools, genetically encoded reporters, and high-resolution imaging techniques have revolutionized our understanding of pericyte structure, organization, and physiology. This literature review aims to synthesize current knowledge on the role of pericytes in blood flow control, with a focus on the brain and heart, and to explore the novel concept of electro-metabolic signaling. In the brain, pericytes have been shown to play a vital role in neurovascular coupling, the process by which neuronal activity triggers local increases in blood flow. Attwell et al. (2016) demonstrated that pericytes can rapidly constrict and dilate capillaries in response to neurotransmitters and vasoactive substances, effectively controlling blood flow at the capillary level. This finding challenged the traditional view that arterioles were the primary regulators of cerebral blood flow. Further supporting this notion, Hall et al. (2014) used two-photon microscopy to show that pericytes respond to neuronal activity faster than smooth muscle cells in arterioles, highlighting their importance in the initial stages of the hemodynamic response. The structural characteristics of brain pericytes have also been elucidated in recent years. Alarcon-Martinez et al. (2020) discovered the presence of tunneling nanotubes connecting pericytes along capillaries, suggesting a potential mechanism for long-distance communication and coordination of vascular responses. These nanotubes may facilitate the propagation of calcium signals and other second messengers, allowing for rapid and coordinated regulation of blood flow across the capillary network. In the heart, pericytes have been found to exhibit distinct features compared to their brain counterparts. Nees et al. (2012) identified a population of cardiac pericytes with unique morphological and functional properties, including the ability to differentiate into other cell types such as fibroblasts and smooth muscle cells. This plasticity suggests a potential role for pericytes in cardiac repair and remodeling. More recently, Yao et al. (2021) described the presence of tunneling microtubes in cardiac pericytes, analogous to the nanotubes found in brain pericytes, but with larger diameters and potentially different functional implications. The concept of electro-metabolic signaling has emerged as a unifying framework to explain how pericytes and vascular smooth muscle cells regulate blood flow in response to tissue metabolic state. This mechanism involves the interplay between ion channels, particularly KATP and Kir2.1 channels, and local metabolic factors. Longden et al. (2017) demonstrated that capillary KATP channels act as metabolic sensors, detecting changes in the ATP/ADP ratio and initiating vasodilatory signals that propagate upstream to arterioles. This finding provides a mechanistic link between local energy demand and blood flow regulation. Building on this work, Harraz et al. (2018) showed that Kir2.1 channels in pericytes and vascular smooth muscle cells play a crucial role in amplifying and propagating vasodilatory signals. The authors proposed that these channels form a regenerative system capable of conducting electrical signals over long distances, allowing for coordinated vascular responses across the microcirculatory network. The distinct spatiotemporal metabolic requirements of the brain and heart may lead to differences in pericyte function and blood flow regulation between these organs. In the brain, rapid and localized changes in neuronal activity necessitate a highly responsive and precise control of blood flow. Kisler et al. (2017) demonstrated that pericyte dysfunction in the brain leads to neurovascular uncoupling and reduced oxygen supply to neurons, highlighting the critical role of pericytes in maintaining cerebral blood flow and cognitive function. In contrast, the heart's metabolic demands are more continuous and homogeneous, reflecting the organ's constant pumping activity. However, cardiac pericytes still play an essential role in regulating coronary microcirculation. Chen et al. (2020) showed that cardiac pericytes contribute to the regulation of coronary blood flow during exercise and ischemia, suggesting a dynamic role in matching blood supply to myocardial oxygen demand. Despite these advances, several important questions remain unanswered. The molecular mechanisms underlying pericyte contraction and relaxation are not fully understood, particularly in the context of electro-metabolic signaling. Additionally, the relative contributions of pericytes and smooth muscle cells to blood flow regulation in different vascular beds and under various physiological and pathological conditions require further investigation. In conclusion, recent research has significantly advanced our understanding of pericyte function in blood flow control, particularly in the brain and heart. The discovery of tunneling nanotubes and microtubes, along with the concept of electro-metabolic signaling, has provided new insights into the mechanisms of vascular regulation. Future studies should focus on elucidating the molecular pathways involved in pericyte-mediated blood flow control and exploring the therapeutic potential of targeting pericytes in vascular and metabolic disorders.
